action.action-desc: Mr. Van Drew introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To require retail electric utilities to notify electric consumers of rate increases, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Protecting Our Wallets from Excessive Rates Act or the POWER Act.

section.header: Notification requirements for planned rate increases

paragraph.text: A retail electric utility that intends to increase any rate applicable to electric consumers shall, in accordance with this subsection, provide notification to electric consumers that will be impacted by the rate increase at least 30 days prior to implementing the rate increase.
A notification provided under paragraph (1) shall include the following:

subparagraph.text: A clear statement of the percentage of the rate increase.
A detailed breakdown of the reasons and justifications for the rate increase.
An explanation of how the increased rate will impact the average electric consumer’s bill.
Information on how electric consumers can provide feedback or file a complaint regarding the rate increase.

paragraph.text: A retail electric utility shall provide notification under paragraph (1) using multiple communication channels to ensure, to the extent feasible, that all impacted electric consumers are provided such notification, including by providing notification by direct mail or email to such electric consumers, posting the notification on the retail electric utility’s official website, and publishing the notification in local newspapers and other local media outlets.

subparagraph.text: A retail electric utility that violates or fails or refuses to comply with the notification requirement under paragraph (1)—

clause.text: shall be subject to a civil penalty in an amount not to exceed $10,000; and
may not implement the applicable rate increase until such notification requirement is met.

subparagraph.text: A penalty under subparagraph (A) shall be assessed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission after notice and opportunity for public hearing. In determining the amount of such a penalty, the Commission shall take into consideration the nature and seriousness of the violation, failure, or refusal and the efforts of the retail electric utility to remedy the violation, failure, or refusal in a timely manner.

paragraph.text: A retail electric utility shall submit to the Secretary of Energy a notification of any planned rate increase of 5 percent or more for any rate applicable to electric consumers, at least 60 days prior to the implementation of such rate increase.
A notification submitted under paragraph (1) shall include—

subparagraph.text: identification of the percentage by which the rate will be increased;
a comprehensive justification for such rate increase, including cost drivers and financial impact;
an assessment of the potential impacts on electric consumers; and
any proposed mitigation measures to be taken by the retail electric utility.
upon receiving a notification under this subsection, review the justification described in paragraph (2)(B); and
not later than 30 days after receiving a notification under this subsection, publish a report on the Secretary’s findings regarding the applicable planned rate increase, including—

clause.text: an assessment of the potential impacts on electric consumers; and

subclause.text: for adjustments to the planned rate increase;
on ways to mitigate the impacts of the rate increase on electric consumers, including—

item.text: financial aid options for electric consumers; and

subclause.text: for how the retail electric utility can improve or increase efficiency to avoid future rate increases.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Energy shall, after a rate increase described in paragraph (1) is implemented, monitor the impacts of such rate increase on the market and on electric consumers to evaluate if the rate increase has had the impacts described in paragraph (3)(B) and if further action is needed.
The term electric consumer has the meaning given such term in section 3(5) of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (16 U.S.C. 2602(5)).
The term electric utility has the meaning given such term in section 3(4) of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (16 U.S.C. 2602(4)).
The term retail electric utility means an electric utility that sells electric energy for purposes other than resale.
